content: The Act is titled the "Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009" and defines various terms. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include new definitions for "private fund" and "foreign private fund adviser." The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to define a "foreign private fund adviser" as an investment adviser with no US office, fewer than 15 US clients, and less than $25,000,000 in US client assets. A "foreign private fund adviser" under the amended Investment Advisers Act of 1940 must have fewer than 15 clients in the US and assets under management for US clients of less than $25,000,000. They should also not hold themselves out as an investment adviser to the public in the US. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 defines a "foreign private fund adviser" as having fewer than 15 US clients and assets under management for US clients of less than $25,000,000. They should not hold themselves out as an investment adviser to the public in the US. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 defines a "foreign private fund adviser" as having fewer than 15 US clients and assets under management for US clients of less than $25,000,000. They should not act as an investment adviser to any registered investment company under the Investment Company Act of 1940. Elimination of private adviser exemption; limited exemption for foreign private fund advisers; limited intrastate exemption. Amendment to Section 203(b) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 includes changes for investment advisers to private funds and foreign private fund advisers. Amendment to Section 203(b) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 includes changes for investment advisers to private funds and foreign private fund advisers. The amendment adds provisions for investment advisers solely advising small business investment companies. The amendment to Section 203(b) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 includes provisions for investment advisers to private funds and foreign private fund advisers, as well as those solely advising small business investment companies. The amendment to Section 203(b) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 allows small business investment companies, entities with pending license applications, and related applicants to qualify for a license. SEC. 4. COLLECTION OF SYSTEMIC RISK DATA. Section 204 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to require registered investment advisers to maintain records and file reports regarding private funds advised by them, as deemed necessary by the Commission for the public interest. The Commission can require registered investment advisers to maintain records and file reports on private funds for the public interest and investor protection. The Commission can provide reports or records to entities responsible for systemic risk assessment, including the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. Private fund records maintained by registered investment advisers may be shared for regulatory purposes. The Commission can share reports and records with entities responsible for systemic risk assessment. Private fund records maintained by registered investment advisers are considered the adviser's own records. Under this Act, records and reports of the investment adviser must include information on assets under management, leverage, counterparty credit risk exposures, trading positions, and practices for each private fund advised. The investment adviser must provide information on assets under management, leverage, counterparty credit risk exposures, trading positions, and practices, as well as other relevant details determined by the Commission in consultation with the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. The Commission may require private fund advisers to report additional information deemed necessary for the public interest, investor protection, or systemic risk assessment. The Commission may require private fund advisers to report additional information for the public interest, investor protection, or systemic risk assessment, with different reporting requirements based on fund types or sizes. Registered investment advisers must maintain records. The SEC may set varying reporting requirements for private fund advisers based on fund types or sizes to address systemic risk. Registered investment advisers must maintain records of private funds advised for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. Registered investment advisers must maintain records of private funds advised under the Act for the Commission's prescribed period to protect investors and assess systemic risk through periodic examinations. Registered investment advisers must allow the Commission to examine records of private funds they advise to assess systemic risk. Registered investment advisers must provide the Commission with access to their records for examinations, as prescribed by the Commission. They must also make copies or extracts of records available without undue effort, expense, or delay upon request. Additionally, the Commission will share information with the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve. The Commission requires registered investment advisers to provide access to their records for examinations and share information with the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve and other entities identified as having systemic risk responsibility. The Commission requires investment advisers to provide reports and information to assess systemic risk of private funds. The Board or other identified entities may request necessary documents, which will be kept confidential as per Commission's guidelines. The purpose of assessing systemic risk of private funds involves providing reports, records, and documents to investors, counterparties, and creditors as required by the Commission. Information obtained must be kept confidential according to Commission guidelines. An investment adviser registered under this Act must provide reports, records, and documents to investors, counterparties, and creditors of private funds as required by the Commission for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. The Commission ensures the confidentiality of these reports. The Commission may prescribe necessary rules for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. Reports filed with the Commission are confidential and cannot be disclosed, except to Congress or in compliance with information requests. The Commission can disclose reports filed with them to Congress or other federal agencies, self-regulatory organizations, or courts in certain circumstances. The Commission can disclose reports to Congress, federal agencies, self-regulatory organizations, or courts as required by law. SEC. 5 eliminates a disclosure provision in the Investment Advisers Act of 1940. SEC. 6 provides an exemption for and reporting requirements by venture capital fund advisers. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to provide an exemption for venture capital fund advisers from registration requirements, with the Commission defining the term 'venture capital fund' and requiring advisers to maintain records and provide necessary reports. The Commission requires exempt venture capital fund advisers to maintain records and provide necessary reports for investor protection. SEC. 7. EXEMPTION OF AND REPORTING BY CERTAIN PRIVATE FUND ADVISERS. Section 203 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to provide an exemption from registration requirements for investment advisers of private funds with assets under management in the US of less than $150,000,000. The Commission will also require exempted advisers to maintain reporting. Exemption from registration requirements for investment advisers of private funds with assets under $150,000,000 in the US. The Commission will require exempted advisers to maintain records and provide necessary reports. The Commission requires exempted advisers of private funds with assets under $150,000,000 to maintain records and provide necessary reports. For mid-sized private fund advisers, regulations will consider fund size, governance, and investment strategy to determine systemic risk and establish registration and examination procedures. The Commission will consider the size, governance, and investment strategy of mid-sized private funds to determine systemic risk and establish registration and examination procedures for investment advisers. SEC. 8. CLARIFICATION OF RULEMAKING AUTHORITY. Section 211 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to grant the Commission authority to make, amend, and rescind rules and regulations necessary for its functions, including defining technical terms and classifying persons and matters based on size. The Commission has the authority to classify persons and matters within its jurisdiction based on various factors and may prescribe different requirements for different classes. The Commission can classify persons and matters based on factors like size, scope, business model, compensation scheme, and systemic risk. Different requirements can be prescribed for different classes, and terms can have different meanings, excluding the term 'client' for investors in private funds managed by investment advisers. The Commission can classify persons and matters based on factors like size, scope, business model, compensation scheme, and systemic risk. Different requirements can be prescribed for different classes, and terms can have different meanings, excluding the term 'client' for investors in private funds managed by investment advisers. The Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission have the authority to determine necessary meanings for terms used in different sections of the title. The Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission will jointly establish rules for reports to be filed with the Commission under sections 203(l) and after consulting with the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. The Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, in consultation with the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, will jointly establish rules for reports to be filed by investment advisers registered under both the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and the Commodity Exchange Act. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to assess the costs on industry members and investors due to registration and reporting requirements under the Act. A report will be submitted to Congress within 2 years. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE; TRANSITION PERIOD. This Act and its amendments will take effect for investment advisers after a 1-year transition period from the enactment date. The Securities and Exchange Commission will establish rules allowing advisers to register before the deadline. SEC. 11. QUALIFIED CLIENT STANDARD. Section 205(e) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to require the Commission to adjust for inflation every 5 years for any dollar amount test used in making determinations. Adjustments not multiples of $1,000 will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $1,000.
